reviewText: Definitely aimed at the armchair paleontologist, and doesn't always make clear what is pure theory and what is known-- I think most viewers would probably understand that just about everything we "know" about dinosaurs is conjecture, but the narration text could be a bit more precise about that.  While experience and observation have helped us make a lot of sense out of the jumble of fossilized Dinosaur bones, behavior itself of course, does not fossilize.  Everything we believe we know about these creatures is extrapolated from bone desposits and observation of (very distant) living dino relatives.The effects are pretty decent, but it doesn't take a sharp eye to realize much of the animation was cannibalized from other shows.  With all that said, I was already aware of much of the information given so if you're "experienced" at this sort of thing, or have done a lot of reading/research on your own, there is likely not much for you in this series.I do agree with some other reviewers, that the sea-creature episode was the best, and seemed to have the most interesting bits.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The ocean episode was good - the other two were gawdawful and stomach turning.  How many times did we gave to see the same animal slaughtered over and over?  They forget kids love to watch dinosaur documentaries and don't need to see the same blood splattering constantly - makes its point the first time.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Maybe I'm not the sort of person this program was made for, and yes it is understood that programs like these are based purely on conjecture, but when the inaccuracies are overwhelming (notably, the Spinosaurus episode) you have to wonder what the point is.  Each program is basically the same as the next, and since the individual shows are very repetitive (showing the same scenes and making the same statements over and over again), you're going to snooze after a while.  I'm sure your kids won't care too much (unless they are discriminating dino fans and will be annoyed by the inaccuracies), but adults will be better served by the "Walking" series or any of the History Channel dino specials.  As it is, I am very disappointed in this program.
summary: Lots of inaccuracies - so-so CGI - kids might like it anyway...

reviewText: They drag it out by repeating themselves every ten minute segment - lots of filler.The animations are reasonable - I'm sure state of the art at the time.These could have been half-hour shows and covered the material just fine.And... I would like to know the scientific name of the "Terror Bird", which is never given.Reasonably entertaining, somewhat informatiive.

reviewText: Monsters resurrected is a fascinating and enjoyable tv programs about the prehistoric monsters that lived in the past like the giant terror birds,africa`s biggest meat eating dinosaur spinosaurus,the mosasaurs giant aquatic marine reptiles that ate sharks and other marine animals,prehistoric mammal predators that lived in north america and one of the most terrifying dinosaur predators that ever lived in north america acrocanthosaurus more dangerous than t-rex.My favorite is australia`s most terrifying predator megalania the giant ripper lizard that is three times bigger than its modern day descendant the komodo dragon.The last disc is about the extinction of the mega beasts and what killed them very interesting stuff.This dvd series is fascinating and fun and takes you back in time to a world of exciting and monstrous and gigantic creatures.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I thoroughly enjoyed the Monsters Resurrected discs and the episodes on them. They were informative, entertaining & have much re-watch value. The only reason that this dvd set is getting 4 stars and not a full five is that there is an episode missing from the series. According to the packaging, there are supposed to be episodes about the following animlas: Terror Bird, Mosasaur, Spinosaurus, Acrocanthosaurus, Megalania & the Bear Faced Dog. The Bear Faced Dog episode is absent from the DVDs. Now granted they included a bonus documentary called "What Killed the Mega Beasts" and it was also very good, but what about The Bear Faced Dog? What the Hell? I just really wish that episode had come with the set. I hope that Discovery Channel will release another DVD set with more Mega Beastepisodes and that the Bear Faced Dog will be included. Until then, I am feeling kind of gyped due to the missinig episode.
summary: fun series, but where's the missing episode?

reviewText: This series was fascinating.  The graphics were very realistic, you could almost believe the creatures still exist.  Learned a lot too.  I don't know I would let real young children watch, but it could stir an interest in science in older ones.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Hard to take.  The same information is repeated over and over, practically word for word, several times during each program.  On top of that, the same CGI dinosaurs scenes (mediocre at best) are also shown over and over and over, ad nauseum.  The BBC program "Walking With Dinosaurs" is much more educational, interesting and worth the money.  Leave "Monsters Reurrected" on the shelf if you see it -- you'll miss nothing, unless you need a sleeping aid.

reviewText: I always loved these kind of series. People who expect Hollywood graphics and script really is expecting too much. I just love these semi sci-fi series. A lot of educated assumptions based on science. We may learn something tomorrow that changes everything but these are still informative and fun.
